Being able to access water quickly is vital. Having sprinklers set up ready before evacuation is what saved our house. Swimming pool and fire pump ready.Start and retreat till ember attack passes. Use face and eye protection. Gloves, leather souled boots, back pack fire spray. Block all vents and door spaces. Steel cover for sky lights. Battery back up for lights. Rake inflammable materials away from walls.  Check for embers after the fire front has gone through. Especially attics and roof spaces. Cheers from Australia.

Last year the areawhere  I live suffered thru two major forest fires...a couple hundred miles apart. First off, forest fires are unusual in our area, especially in early spring. However,we didn't get much snow over the winter,so forests were unnaturally dry. Thousands of acres were lost, hundreds of homes and businesses wiped outüò¢ NOT once did politics enter the discussion! NOT once!! Both areas destroyed were a mix of lower income and very wealthy,yet that had no bearing on anything. EVERYONE was treated as equals,everyone pulled together to help. There were no conspiracy theories,there were no lies being spread by the news. Not once were politics mentioned. No hate,no lies,just hope and help. The cause was determined after thorough investigation to be an older lady burning garbage in one area and teens having a bonfire in a other. No lasers,no government interference,just human error. Why does it seem that every disaster in the Divided States recently is shrouded in hate,false news and political strife?? Shouldn't kindness, generosity and support of all people be the most important thing?? The future looks sad for AmeriKKKa üíî

I have lived in Los Angeles since 1974 and never experienced anything like this. I have always acknowledged that a horrible earthquake was possible but never considered a wildfire as they always seemed relegated to outlying areas without a lot of populace. It was unnerving but I got out right away when I saw the Prepare for Evacuation emergency notice on my phone. I no longer drive but two neighbors offered to take me with them to wherever they were going. I was shocked I was able to get a Lyft ride to a friend's place as quickly as I did despite gridlock traffic caused by people in panic leaving. I am 73. My sense of security and safety living in L.A. has received a chilling wake-up call. I now look askance at every dry palm tree and bush and fear the rising winds. But every area of the USA had some kind of dangerous threat, does it not? I survived tornados in the Midwest long before I moved to L.A. and also survived the Northridge earthquake here in the '90s. Prepare the best you can but don't live in denial.

They rarely gust to 40mph, but the ones in LA last week were only about 25. I know because I checked. really stupid people could mistake it for a 100mph wind, supposing they had never been anywhere near a 100mph wind. I'm 83 born and raised in LA.  Since as far back as I remember, my parents loved the going to the beach and driving up and down the Pacific Coast Highway from Santa Monica To Zuma passing thru Malibu.  All those homes and families were already there since I was 4 or 5 years old.  Back then we knew some celebs lived along the beach like Cary Grant, Bing Crosby and Barbara Stanwyck.  We weren't jealous or envious of them.  We had a game trying to guess who lived in which house.  Or who was that washing their car parked in front of their garage?  But we also knew regular people lived there too.  

It was the Rivera of Southern California.  My mom's favorite thing was to have fresh Lobster Tails at one of the great seafood restaurants along the way.  One time we rented horses and rode down Topanga Canyon to the beach just to have lunch.  My parents are gone.  We did this outing frequently over the years into their mid 90's.  Now all that beauty and all those lives, and all that can be seen and experienced by others instantly evaporated by an 75mph firestorm of destruction and destroyed lives.  All thats left are memories ... some heartfelt and some horrific, and some filled with contempt.

I've been on evacuation alert twice in the past 20 years and was evacuated last year where the fire came within 250 metres of my property where over 300 residences burned. A similar number burned on the other side of the city in 2003 here in southern British Columbia.

My advise:
1. Pressure your municipal government to cut fireguards around your neighbourhood and shut down your neighbour Goretex dog hikers objectors who don't want to travel an extra 10 minutes to walk Fido in the forest. Forests in nature burn every now and then. That's just what they do. Decades of no fires and increases in city's growing circumferences is a recipe for disaster. Our forests are overgrown, over mature and ready to burn even without the excuse of climate change.

2. Do an inventory of EVERYTHING you own by making a spreadsheet of photos with each item in the photo listed with replacement value as per your insurance policy. It will take you a few days once in your lifetime but it will be the first thing the insurance company will ask for...after the fire but never before. Update it each year. Imagine the satisfaction of walking into your insurance company with a document like this and handing to your agent who is masquerading like someone who cares about you. 

3. Keep special heirlooms and items you seldom use in clearly marked BugOut Boxes. Stick a list to a box of stuff on display that you want to keep for quick collection.

4. Keep digital photos on the cloud. Put your aluminum foil hat away as no one cares about what they are amongst the trillions of photos out there.

5. Remember...it's wood, glass, nails and pipes that will be replaced. Memories are in the heart. Put a bit of cold, heartless mindset on in dealing with it. It helps.

The Fire Chief that said the Jan 1 fire was ‚Äú‚Ä¶dead out,‚Äù is Dead Wrong. Claiming that the possibility of a rekindle of the New Year‚Äôs Eve as some kind of ‚Äúphenomenon‚Äù is uninformed. Fires are chemistry and physics. The pyrotechnic residue from spent fireworks mixed with the ashes and charcoal of the brush sitting in direct sunlight in 90¬∞ F temps for 7 days was enough to trigger a second fire. The ruins of any fire can rekindle if the post fire environment is right for re-ignition. LAFD made the black burnt brush wet, but it dried out, and when it gets dried out from the heat and wind it breaks down and heats up. It‚Äôs called Heat of Decomposition. Remember the primary chemical ingredients in fireworks is gun powder, potassium nitrate, charcoal and sulfur. The mixture of these chemicals become just as flammable and explosive after they dry out as they were before they got wet. Once the dried gunpowder residue becomes hot enough it becomes a highly volatile accelerant that if reignited can worsen fire conditions in a brush fire quickly. All it takes to get the situation right for a rekindle is to raise the temperature of the fuels above Heat of Decomposition (under 300¬∞ F) to the pyrolytic temperature of smoke (above 300¬∞ F). 
We got an old saying in the fire service:
‚ÄúWhere There‚Äôs Smoke There‚Äôs Fire.‚Äù
Author unknown (and probably prehistoric but definitely not a phenomenon).

I helped with a house on fire once, and within 5 minutes, I was no longer able to approach the front door, even crawling low on my belly. I

It only  took about 5 min total for this lady's home to catch fire. Her Husband told me that she had a bad habit of smoking on the couch in their converted garage, and fall asleep, dropping the butt onto the couch. I was on my way to work from lunch break and drove by and saw this woman standing outside this converted garage quietly saying, "fire", "fire", "fire", rather quietly, while I passed by. 

I noticed the smoke starting to become visible, emanating from her converted porch while parking along the curbing. I approached her at the front of her house and she was in a strange mental state and was not giving me any valid information. 

I then asked her if anyone was in the house, and she said, "yes, My Husband is in the back room, and he has one leg". I then ran up to the front door and began screaming for him to vacate, but I did not hear anyone in the back as the fire already had spread to the front door from the converted garage and the roar was becoming deafening. The front door approach was okay, at first, and about 3 minutes passed so far, but it was growing fast and I did have to crouch low to try and enter the home and look for her husband, but things quickly changed upon opening the front door and a backdraft was created that seemed to move the fire to the front instead of spreading to the back, making the front door entirely inaccessible. I began yelling for the man to go out the back,  and then I finally heard a man yelling that he was crawling out the back. 

I left before the fire dept came as I had to go back to work, but both husband and wife were okay, but shaken up from the fire of course. They did manage to put out the fire, but the damages to the roof and garage were excessive. I noticed volunteer groups on that property days later, and a huge group began to repair it, finishing it all up within a week so they could move back in. 

The lesson I learned in all this is... You only get about 5 minutes once a couch catches on fire.

[Added January 18, 2025: But back to the winds. As I said, and as you know, everyone on both sides is pushing 100mph Santa Ana winds to explain this, including the weather expert Bill Burr. One problem: there is no such thing. Look it up if you don't believe me. Start with the Beaufort Scale, where you will learn that 100mph winds are normally only found in cyclones, like hurricanes and tornados. Strong Santa Ana winds never hit 100 or even 50. They rarely gust to 40mph, but the ones in LA last week were only about 25. I know because I checked. It is quite easy to do these days, just go to one of the many weather channels and type in the zip code. 25mph is a strong wind, and I guess
 
really stupid people could mistake it for a 100mph wind, supposing they had never been anywhere near a 100mph wind. To give you a comparison, a gale is defined as about 40-45mph, and that can knock you over and cause 25ft waves at sea. A strong gale is 45-55mph, and that can tear shingles off your house. That wasn't happening in LA, because Santa Ana winds never hit strong gale or Beaufort 9. Beaufort 10 is full gale or storm, with winds up to 63mph. As it says at Wiki, this is almost never seen inland, and it will uproot trees and blow houses down. Beaufort 11 is up to 72mph, causing 50ft waves at sea. Even most sailors have never experienced this, and they don't want to. Anything above 73mph is hurricane, Beaufort 12, so the talking heads in LA are claiming way above hurricane force winds hit Palisades on Tuesday. Which is how I knew they were lying immediately.]
